In Dec 2015, 196 countries agreed to the landmark # ParisAgreement on # ClimateChange, pledging to fight the climate crisis. Its goal is to keep this century’s temperature increase well below 2°C, & further, to limit the increase to 1.5°C.

And the response to this tweet by some is testimony to the way that well-meaning folks have been duped and weaponized into a culture war over language, distracting from the task at hand--communicating the distinct threat posed by fossil fuel burning and climate change.

Scientists won’t— and shouldn’t - alter the SCIENTIFIC lexicon for political purposes. People are welcome to characterize climate change as a crisis. It doesn’t mean SCIENTISTS should alter their descriptions of physical processes. I’m disheartened that I even have to say this.

The *physical phenomenon* we are talking about is human-caused *climate change*. That's the term scientists use and *should* use in describing it. The impacts & implications arguably constitute a *crisis*. What terminology is most appropriate depends entirely on the context.

Global warming/climate change are complimentary terms used by scientists depending on context. Climate change refers to changes in the stats — averages AND extremes. We can see the impact in recent unprecedented weather extremes. See my op-Ed: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/its-not-rocket-science-climate-change-was-behind-this-summers-extreme-weather/2018/11/02/b8852584-dea9-11e8-b3f0-62607289efee_story.html?utm_term=.c7e25a23ab1d …

Earth Day ends and people outside of the climate movement stop talking to me... something’s not right 

Earth Day is Every Day!! Get involved and use your passion to drive change 🌍❤️
That being said— isn’t it funny that when a Tick-Tock argument happens every media talks about it, but when a climate activist argument happens all we know is what we find on Twitter?

Even if the role of a climate activist is to inspire people to be an activist— that’s enough because we can’t ask everything from everyone 

That being said, calling ppl IN (u know what I mean) is necessary for growth

We’re all learning and the climate movement must allow that

Just as all of us have different skills, the parts of the climate movement have different purposes

We need an org that works for climate education, we need another one that works with lawmakers, we need another one that calls out lawmakers— disrespecting this won’t get us far

My take on today’s Climate Activism— the youth movement has definitely become my home for the past year. And in homes, sometimes people argue and disagree

But that doesn’t mean that we aren’t together under the same roof

That doesn’t mean that we don’t have to coexist tomorrow

Damn, I describe the weather and people talk about the climate. I describe the climate, and people talk about the weather

And the Climate Crisis is increasing the frequency and intensity of El Niño, so you see the point? More fossil fuels, more global heating, stronger El Niño events, and I get no snow in the city.

Remember, the world doesn’t change when 1,000 people do climate-justice activism perfectly, it changes when billions of people do it the best they can

8- Meet people where they’re at —> not everyone knows the climate crisis back and forth. Explain it and present solutions 

9- Use accessible language. Not everyone knows about PPM (parts per million), or the IPCC (intergovernmental panel on climate change)

6- At events that you hold, invite indigenous peoples to do land acknowledgements, and remember that indigenous knowledge is the foundation for addressing the climate crisis

7- Always convey that individual and structural change are both indisputably necessary

10 tips for being a climate justice activist:

1- Don’t start from scratch, there are hundreds of existing initiatives that you can join

2- Maintain good communication with your peers and the adult organizations that you partner with

3- Take good care of yourself and others

Tomorrow is my 52nd climate strike in front of the U.N.
ONE YEAR.
When I began striking, I was angry over the outcome at COP 24. Now, on my 52nd week, I leave for COP 25 in Madrid. World leaders have given youth no choice. We will continue taking action until our future is safe.
"climate change is a human rights issue" 👇  https://twitter.com/amnesty/status/1201440465465348096 …

Now, I look forward to attending COP 25, where I'll be able to talk to decision makers about our case & what it means for our generation. The climate crisis is violating our basic human rights & recent dire climate reports show it's only getting worse.
The time to act is NOW /end

This is a big deal because there's never been a case as complicated as ours, with multiple petitioners (like myself) and multiple respondents (France, Turkey, Germany, Argentina, Brazil) on a global issue as huge as the climate crisis./2

6/ We need address the climate crisis to not only to prevent the loss of physical life, but also the loss of the part of our life that is our heritage and ancestry.
Thank you @SDSNYouth @CasinaPioIV and everyone at #VYS19 for such a heartfelt experience this week.
/End

5/I am looking forward to working with my new friends from Mexico and Latin America. As I travel, I've added Mexico City to my list of destinations to learn more about the climate crisis and also about myself. Under climate change, "loss of life" has a double meaning.

4/Because of the climate crisis, we will not only lose species, ecosystems and land, we will lose parts of ourselves. Of course there will be loss of human life, but many of us who remain will be half-dead when we lose our cultures and even our languages. I understand this now.

3/This week I’m with people who speak Spanish and live the culture & what should be my language and culture feels so foreign to me. I’ve also learned that because of inhospitable climate conditions, my own ancestors were forced to migrate north in search of a better life.

Every day is another chance to educate yourself about this climate crisis and understand the seriousness of it. If you are sheltering in place right now. Here are three films you can watch to start:
1. Before the Flood
2. Chasing Coral
3. Dark Waters

Climate striking isn't about the amount of work young people are putting in, it is about the lack of work everyday people aren't. doing. We need you to join us, this is your planet too, this is your fight. A hurricane, drought, or wildfire is not partisan, so that is no excuse.

I am advocating for the Climate Change Education Act to pass both the house and the senate. I am striking for the implementation of the Green New Deal Mobilization. I am striking because we need substantive and revolutionary action at COP26. We are striking for all of our lives!

People tend to forget that we climate strike for reason, not the photo-ops or becoming famous. It is about advocating for a real policy difference. A climate strike is not and should not become a symbolic act, this started as a real and necessary shock to the status quo.

I’m tired of people categorizing me as a single issue activist.

I am NOT a single issue activist.

Does the majority of the work I do revolve around #climatejustice? Yes.

But the climate crisis is connected to ALL other issues. I fight for justice for all, not only the climate.

The climate crisis doesn’t exist in a vacuum.

It’s not like environmental issues are floating separately from social justice issues. 

The climate crisis is a product of societal systems, and those societal systems are racist, sexist, colonial, and rooted in injustice.

50 years since Earth Day launched, what's changed? 

Join @nytimes reporter @jswatz on 4/24, 11:30am EST, with organizer of the first Earth Day @DenisHayes, @vanessa_vash, and myself for a conversation about the future of climate change! 

RSVP:  http://nyti.ms/2wZwiWm  pic.twitter.com/wx29ALfanX
climate justice = social justice

People ask me why I fight for climate justice instead of fighting for other causes.

But I actually didn't pick one issue over another. I'm NOT a single issue activist. 

The climate crisis is interconnected with all other issues in our world. 

Climate justice IS social justice.

Let's stop normalizing ableism in environmentalism.

This whole obsession with shaming individuals who don't have the resources or ability to be perfectly eco-friendly is not okay.

The real cause of the climate crisis is corporate greed, put your energy into addressing that.

Climate Justice is not about shaming the individual for not being perfectly eco-friendly at all times, it's about building inclusive movements to create systematic change that addresses the root causes of the climate crisis.

How Climate Activist Jamie Margolin Plans to Save the World (and Graduate High School) 

“There’s no pride in doing the bare minimum, and there’s no pride in standing in the center when there are two clear sides: life or death.”
- @Seattlemag https://www.seattlemag.com/news/how-climate-activist-jamie-margolin-plans-save-world-and-graduate-high-school …

I love activism and I'm proud of the work I've done for climate justice. For as long as I live, I will always be fighting for what is right.

But you also have to understand that activism while you're in High School is a LOT to handle. 

I'm 18. Sometimes I just want to be a kid.

I deprived myself of teenage experiences to be a climate activist.

Because I am constantly speaking, organizing, and working, I never had the time to be a kid.

I thought the end of Senior year would be my one chance to finally have some typical teenage experiences, like prom.
To all the people sending me homophobic slurs in my DMs....jokes on you, I am *the* climate dyke.  pic.twitter.com/12lSeM26jF

Systems of exploitation caused the climate crisis.

Colonialism caused climate change.

Capitalism caused climate change.

Those who are at the top of those systems who exploit people and the earth are to blame for climate change.

 Not humanity in itself. Not ALL old people.

When we push this narrative of "climate change is the fault of ALL old people", it erases the work of indigenous elders & older community leaders who have been fighting for #climatejustice since before I was born.

We youth activists are standing on the shoulders of their work.

Older generations DID cause the climate crisis, but it is only certain members of them.

My grandma who grew up living off the land in Colombia, respecting every living thing around her didn't cause the #climatecrisis.

It's the POLITICIANS & CORPORATIONS, not "all old people."

I don't believe in pitting generations against each other. 

When people say "#boomers caused the climate crisis" it's actually 100 corporations that caused climate change. 

In order for the climate movement to be successful, we must be united and intergenerational.

Dear Politicians,

You said urgent action on climate is impossible.

You told me that it doesn't matter how series the climate crisis is, "the show must always go on."

Well, the show has stopped.

So if you can stop the world for #COVID — can you do the same for #climatechange?

The lifestyles of the richest 0.54% in the world — 42 million people — are emitting more greenhouse gas emissions than the poorest half of the global population —3.8 billion people.

"Humanity" isn't what caused the climate crisis.

Capitalism did.

Ecofascism is a dangerous ideology that sees crises like #COVID19 that kill vulnerable people as good because in their minds it's "good for the planet when people die."

But "overpopulation" is not the problem here! Climate change was caused by corporations not "too many people."

Please stop celebrating the #coronavirus as some sort of blessing in disguise simply because pollution has gone down due to quarantines.

“The weak will die but it’s okay because it helps the climate” is not climate justice.

That is Ecofascism.

NOVEMBER (pt. 1) 🏆 

November began with the @mtvema awards! 
I was honored to win an #MTVema for my #climatejustice work, & I had the privilege of going to Seville Spain to speak on the @MTV red carpet about climate, as well as doing different events with the Seville community.  pic.twitter.com/yQaRMOgUol

OCTOBER (pt. 2)💃🏻

Next, I went to London after being named one of the @BBC100women of 2019 to accept the honor and speak about climate justice at @BBCWorld headquarters!

After London, I took off to Querétaro Mexico to give my first climate talk in Spanish in Latin America!  pic.twitter.com/wgpl6ctU3i

OCTOBER (pt. 1) 💃🏻

October was defined by my European tour!

First I went the the @c40cities in Copenhagen & met an amazing community of Latinx activists. I got to speak at the Danish climate strike & represent the youth at a press conference launching the global green new deal!  pic.twitter.com/ZdkB4tfKW9

SEPTEMBER (pt. 5) 💥

 I also took part in a massive campaign with @patagonia , blasting the climate strike message on billboards all over.

After all the craziness of the #ClimateStrikes I returned to my roots by giving a climate justice presentation to my old elementary school.  pic.twitter.com/6vTUHFD4H7

SEPTEMBER (pt. 4)

In September, the mainstream TV news media finally gave youth climate activists a megaphone, and I was honored to be on the @VanJones68 show, @craigmelvin show & @allinwithchris + @UnivisionNews @NBCUTelemundo & many other @CBS @CNN & @MSNBC talking on climate!  pic.twitter.com/t0DosFmPRH

AUGUST (pt. 2)👊🏼

In August I also got to go to Puerto Rico for the @theICYV to meet with young change makers from all over the world! Then I spoke at a conference in Minnesota then went to IOWA for an off-grid @FutureCoalition retreat to plan the September 20th climate strikes!  pic.twitter.com/bDSkmGD1R6

July (pt 2) 🌴

After the #YouthClimateSummit in Miami, I took off to NYC to speak at the @UN on a @UNDP panel about climate justice (I also filmed for a documentary project I’m working on 😉).

July was also full of publishing articles & doing press & follow ups from the summit!  pic.twitter.com/h9tdudk7Po

JUNE ☀️

June was defined by organizing @ThisIsZeroHour ‘s #YouthClimateSummit & doing press, publishing articles & giving speeches on climate!

I gave the keynote at @OceanHeroesHQ, wrote an Op-Ed for @TeenVogue & met so many amazing youth & adult activists I’ve always admired! pic.twitter.com/1e75h3nbmQ

MAY (pt 2)🎤 

I also won a @TheCommonGood scholarship alongside @AlexandriaV2005 and gave a speech about how adults need to support youth activists.

Then I joined @AlexandriaV2005 to #ClimateStrike for the #AmazonRainforest at the @UN to protest government inaction on climate!  pic.twitter.com/Xz8q9bxBJD

April (pt 2) 🌎

April was also the month I officially started to #ClimateStrike! I also threw myself into writing the manuscript for #YouthToPower. Plus I opened up about my queerness & dreams for the future to @PORTERmagazine, and I told my climate story to @i_D magazine! pic.twitter.com/YNFu1fBTaP

MARCH 🗣

March was a whirlwind of action. I gave a @TEDx talk, I spoke at @Yale about climate, @ThisIsZeroHour launched our #GetToTheRoots campaign and I gave more presentations for it than I can count, did my first Colombian media interviews, & had my story told on Swedish TV. pic.twitter.com/KomxNZEbaB

FEBRUARY ❣️

February was a month of hard work and preparation for bigger things to come. I filmed a campaign with @AlbaBotanica , wrote and memorized my @TEDTalks , helped launch the American #ClimateStrike movement, and worked on organizing the March 15 Seattle climate strike.  pic.twitter.com/Y8l6krhP7B
This is the decade we stop the climate crisis from destroying all life on earth.

We are called Zero Hour because #THISISZEROHOUR to act on the climate crisis. 

We organize marches, trainings, strikes, lobby days, educational campaigns, summits, workshops, social media campaigns, and much more to fight for intersectional solutions to the climate crisis!  pic.twitter.com/ZX002OifUx

So the next time you believe a headline that says youth climate activists are a bunch of brats skipping school and having fun, think again.
⁣
I am not skipping around the globe having fun — I’m hustling, sacrificing, and working my butt off. So are my fellow activists. ⁣
⁣

At my age, skipping school to do climate justice work is a sacrifice. I miss out on classes, get behind on things, my grades drop and I miss hanging out with friends, and important milestones like birthdays in the lives of the people I love.⁣
⁣

I say this not to complain because I am extremely blessed and privileged to be doing everything I am doing, i am saying this to emphasize that this whole myth that youth climate activists just skip school for “fun” and that were puppets just skipping around making noise is FALSE.

People ask me “why are you taking climate action?” as if what I’m doing is something out of this world and crazy.

All life on earth is threatened by this crisis, if you react to an existential threat like climate change with anything OTHER than action, that’s a red flag 🚩!

To anyone who goes on TV and talks about how climate change is not real, I dare you to use those arguments in a court of law.

I dare you to deny climate change under oath.

In a court of law, your climate denial would be be perjury, and that is a crime.

#Youthvgov @youthvgov

The reason why youth are waging lawsuits against our governments over climate change via @youthvgov & the reason why governments are so scared is because we’re guaranteed to win.

Why? 

In a court of law, climate denial is not real.

That’s called perjury. Perjury is a crime.

In a court of law, climate denial does not exist.

That’s called perjury.

It’s so weird to me when people ask me “why are you taking climate action?”

To that I say, “why are you NOT taking climate action?”
For a politician to do anything other than take rapid urgent climate action to save all life on earth before it’s too late is criminal.

The climate crisis does not exist in a vacuum, so those made most vulnerable by society and systems of oppression feel the worst effects of the climate crisis. The more vulnerable you are, the harder you get hit.⁣
⁣

Climate change is a man made problem that demands feminist womxn-led solutions.

Einstein described insanity as trying to solve an issue with the same thinking that caused it.

So why are we trying to solve the climate crisis with the same colonialism and extractive methods that caused it?

You cannot colonize your way out of a problem caused by colonization.
If we do not address the climate crisis for what it is -- the grand culmination of all our societal injustices that have been building up for centuries -- then we're in BIG trouble.
The climate crisis is the grand culmination of all our societal injustices that have been building up for centuries.
Climate change itself is not the main problem, it is a symptom of much larger, deep rooted societal issues that have been building up for centuries.
Climate change is a man made problem, which is why women should rule the world.

You can't properly kill a weed by by just snipping its stem, you have to dig it up from the roots.

You can't properly solve the climate crisis by just addressing the emissions problem, you have to dig deep to the root systems of oppression that caused it in order to solve it.

(1/2) CLIMATE CHANG IMPACT ON MENTAL HEALTH:

A warmer world will mean more people taking their own lives. A study published in Nature found that after a 1 degree C rise in temperature in the United States and Mexico, the suicide rate rose by 0.7% and 2.1%
via @ecobusinesscom

An average of 21.5 million people have been forcibly displaced since 2008 due to climate changed-related weather hazards, according to the @UN High Commissioner For Refugees. 

So if you care about immigration and refugee issues, you also gotta start caring about climate!

If the world warms by 3.7 degrees Celsius, the cost in damage will run to US$551 trillion, more than all the wealth that exists in the world today in property and land.

So climate change will destroy wealth, and wealth is what people have been using as an excuse not to act...

Finally, I also asked these #climate #activists how the #COVID19Pandemic has affected their activism: 53% say that affected them a lot as they can no longer do face-to-face work incl #protests/#strikes. 36% say that it is having a moderate effect as they worked on and offline.

As expected, almost all hosts have participated in a #climate related #protest before EarthDayLive (95%):  95% participated in the #ClimateStrike in 9/2019, 39% participated in the first global #ClimateStrike in 3/2019, & 41% participated in the #PeoplesClimateMarch in 2017
Like previous waves of #activism in the #youth #climate #movement (as well as #theResistance more broadly), women make up the majority of the #activists organizing events--67% identify as female.

Interested in who will be participating in the #youth #climate #movement's #EarthDayLive next week? Here's an early look based on preliminary data collected from hosts of events around the US @FutureCoalition Details of the event are up here:   https://www.earthdaylive2020.org/

1 day into data collection from #EarthDay Live organizers (aka #youth #climate #activists who are planning a huge #digitalstrike). No evidence that these activists support #NeverBiden  (5% response rate so far).

This paper is a strong contribution to the research on the relationship between feelings and political engagement generally and #climate action specifically, but it's worth discussing the measures of #activism/ #mobilization here...

They find that "constructive hope and doubt predict increased policy support & political engagement (around #Climate)...false hope and fatalistic doubt predict the opposite. An interaction exists between constructive hope & doubt in predicting political behavioral intentions"

Just started a new wave of data collection of #youth #climate #activists involved with the upcoming #ClimateStrike  Most notable so far is that only ONE respondent reports their first #protest experience was with the issue of #ClimateChange! #FridaysForFuture @FutureCoalition

BUT there is also some evidence of electoral backlash against #climate #policies.  See this example from @leahstokes using the case of backlash to #windEnergy projects in #Ontario https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/ajps.12220 …

FINALLY (post child dropoff), #civicengagement frequently involves citizens working individually or in groups to change their political representation through #democratic elections of candidates who support more aggressive climate change mitigation strategies

A handful of studies have explored the relationship between #climate #activism and #emissions, with a recent piece by Muñoz, Olzak, and Soule finding that emissions in states decline when there is more pro-environmental #protest protest https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/socf.12422 …

And then there's #protest, which is how people with less access to resources and power challenge the political and economic system.  This tactic includes those taken by the #youth #climate #movement, including the #ClimateStrikes initiated by @GretaThunberg and @Fridays4future

There's not much research that measures the direct effect of participation in these types of #lifestyle #movements as it relates to #climate outcomes, but see this work by @SwedishProtests and colleagues:  https://jspp.psychopen.eu/article/view/903 …

In my project looking at the #youth #climate #movement, I ask for each parent's educational attainment as a proxy.

This finding that many hosts cut their teeth in #TheResistance is consistent with my research on participants in the #youth #climate #movement this summer.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/07/12/youth-climate-summit-starts-today-its-full-young-activists-trained-anti-trump-movement/ …

Just like the demographics of the People's #Climate March in 2017, 77% of the hosts are white (7% are Latinx, 2% Black, 4% Asian, and 4% identify as mixed race).  I've got a lot of "others" here where people tell me stuff like "race isn't important" or "I'm human, duh"

Hosts are older than the general #youth #climate #movement.  Mean age is 36, but 25% are 18 years old or younger and half of them are 25 years or younger (anyone looking to teach the importance of understanding #statistics, here's a good example!).

However, I wonder the degree to which this group is working as part of a #climate #coalition.  History shows us how coalitions of groups with varied ideologies, tactics and constituencies can work effectively for social change (see examples from the #CivilRights #movement

If we think more broadly about the #climate #movement, my sense is that this group has intentionally situated itself on the vanguard as what some might call an actor in the #radical flank.  They are bringing innovative #tactics to the movement.

There were also definitely more diverse that what many expect from an #environmental or #climate #movement (or even the 2014 and 2018 #PeoplesClimateMarch--which I discuss in this chapter in the recent volume on #TheResistance by @davidsmeyer1 and Sid Tarrow) 👇 pic.twitter.com/3jEBeq1EDW

In the end, I counted about 100 people out in front of the @DNC.  They were definitely young--consistent with my current study of the #youth #climate #movement, which has preliminarily found #activists have a mean age of 24 in the US.

As a scholar who's been studying the #climate #movement since the 1990s, I was really interested to see this group in action and to observe how people responded to the call to join their #Debate watching party last night.

It was great to join the folks from @sunrisemvmt at their #protest at the @DNC last night. Comparing data prior to #Election2016 (the ones in this new paper) to 2017 (100 days into the #TrumpAdministration, we find that #EchoChambers have shifted once more and formed around #climate #science and #denial.  In other words, no more echo chambers amplifying consensus.

In summer 2016, there were #EchoChambers in US #climate politics, but they were amplifying consensus around the #CleanPowerPlan rather than discord, which we found in our previous paper in @NatureClimate based on data collected in 2010. https://twitter.com/SethLSanders/status/1040660596130103296 …
